questions.text: The basal cardiac output in adults is around ________
questions.solution:
The basal cardiac output in adults is around 5.5 litres.
Cardiac output is given by, Cardiac Output = Heart Rate X Stroke Volume. 
In a resting, supine man cardiac output averages about 5.0 L/min (70 mL × 72 beats/min).

questions.text: The cardiac output can be determined by all except:
questions.solution:
V/Q ratio not used to determine cardiac output.
Measurement of cardiac output:

  • Fick principle
  • Dye dilution/thermodilution
  • Doppler plus echocardiograph
  • MRI

questions.text: Cardiac output in litre per minute divided by heart rate gives ______
questions.solution:
Cardiac output in litre per minute divided by heart rate gives stroke volume.
Cardiac output is given by, Cardiac Output = Heart Rate X Stroke Volume.
The stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped out of each ventricle per beat, is about 70 mL from each ventricle in a resting man in the supine position.

questions.text: Ejection fraction is
questions.solution:
Ejection fraction is SV/EDV.
The amount of blood ejected by each ventricle per stroke at rest is 70–90 mL. The end-diastolic ventricular volume is about 130 mL. The ejection fraction is the percentage of the end-diastolic ventricular volume that is ejected with each stroke, is about 65%.

questions.text: A patient with cardiac output 5L/min and body surface area 1.7m2. What will be the cardiac index (L/min/m2)?
questions.solution:
Cardiac index  is the cardiac output per minute per square meter of body surface.

Cardiac Index = Cardiac output / body surface area.

Therefore Cardiac index = 5L/min /1.7m2= 2.94 L

questions.text: Volume determining preload is
questions.solution:
Volume determining preload is End diastolic volume.
Preload is the initial stretch on muscle at the end of diastole. Preload is equal to End diastolic volume (EDV) and is determined by venous return to heart.

questions.text: Starling's law implies:

choices.text: Increased heart rate leads to increased cardiac output
Increased discharge leads to increased cardiac output
Increased venous return leads to increased cardiac output
Increased blood pressure leads to increased cardiac output

questions.solution:
Starling's law implies increased venous return leads to increased cardiac output.

Frank-Starling law: The energy of contraction is proportional to the initial length of the cardiac muscle fiber.
The length of the muscle fibers is proportional to the end-diastolic volume, which is determined by venous return.

questions.text: Venous return to the heart during quiet standing is facilitated by all  of the following factors except  _____.

choices.text: Increased arterial  pressure due to gravitation.

questions.solution:
Venous return to the heart during quiet standing is not facilitated by increased arterial pressure.

Factors that facilitate venous return to the heart:

  • Calf muscles contract and pump blood through veins.
  • Valves don't allow the retrograde flow of blood through veins.
  • Deep fascia by forming a supporting structure to veins.        

Note: The pulsations of artery helps in increasing lymph flow .

questions.text: When a person changes position from standing to supine, _______

choices.text: Venous return to heart rises immediately
Decrease in blood flow to the lung apices

questions.solution:
When a person changes position from standing to supine, venous return to heart rises immediately. On standing, Gravitational pull causes venous pooling of blood in the legs. On supine position, this gravitational pull equalizes over body, causing the pooled blood to return back to heart.

Other options:

Option A: Heart rate decreases because of increased cardiac output and increased BP via baroreceptor reflex.
Option C: Cerebral blood flow will remain constant due to autoregulation.
Option D: Blood flow to the apex of lung will be high due to high cardiac output.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. Her pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in mL/min)? (Point 2 corresponds to 120 ml)
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a heart rate of 70-beats/min and the stroke volume can be determined from the given pressure-volume diagram.

Point 2 corresponds to the EDV(End diastolic volume) = 120 mL
Point 1 corresponds to the ESV(End systolic volume) = 50 mL

Thus, stroke volume (SV) = EDV – ESV = 120 – 50 = 70 mL

Therefore, Cardiac output = HR X SV = 70 X 70 = 4900 mL/min.

This is AIIMS pattern question. Detailed and thorough knowledge on cardiac cycle, pressures and volumes is a must for any entrance exam as it a frequently tested topic.

questions.text: A sister donated one of her kidneys to her brother. What would be the effect on her cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Surgical removal of kidney leads to decrease in cardiac output.

Amputation of a limb or surgical removal of organs like kidney removes a parallel circuit thus increasing total peripheral vascular resistance. As the resistance increases, afterload increases hence decreasing stroke volume. 
CO= HR × SV, therefore decrease in stroke volume leads to decrease in cardiac output.

questions.text: The indication of the end of the isovolumetric relaxation phase is when  ____

choices.text: Ventricular pressure raise above atrial pressure
Ventricular pressure falls below atrial pressure
Ventricular pressure falls below aortic pressure
ventricular pressure rises above aortic pressure

questions.solution:
The indication of the end of the isovolumetric relaxation phase is when ventricular pressure falls below atrial pressure. 

Events of the Cardiac Cycle

Diastole 

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with 'a' wave in JVP.

Systole 

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively.

questions.text: During the cardiac cycle, the opening of the aortic valve takes place at the ______
questions.solution:
Opening of the aortic valve takes place at the end of the isovolumetric contraction.

When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonary valves) open, and ventricular ejection begins.

questions.text: The effect of increased heart rate on cardiac cycle is that it____.

choices.text: Decrease the duration of systole and diastole.
Increase the duration of systole and diastole.
Decrease the duration of systole more than diastole.
Decrease the duration of diastole more than systole.

questions.solution:
The effect of increased heart rate on cardiac cycle is that it decreases the duration of diastole more than systole.
The duration of systole is much more fixed than that of diastole, so when the heart rate is increased, diastole is shortened to a much greater degree. Coronary blood flow and ventricular filling occur in diastole.

questions.text: Electromechanical systole is the time interval between _______

choices.text: R wave and first heart sound
Q wave and second heart sound

questions.solution:
Electromechanical systole is the time interval between Q wave and second heart sound.

To record this both ECG and phonocardiography are required.

questions.text: The pressure-volume curve is shifted to the left in:
questions.solution:
The pressure-volume curve is shifted to the left in Mitral stenosis.

The PV loop is shifted to the right when there is volume overload (increased EDV).
The PV loop is shifted to the left in case of increased contractility or decreased compliance (decreased EDV).

Effect of Valvular Diseases on PV loop:

  • Mitral stenosis: Left and down.
  • Mitral regurgitation: Width increased and height decreased.
  • Aortic stenosis: Tall with steep slope.
  • Aortic regurgitation: Right and tall.

questions.text: Dicrotic notch is caused by _________
questions.solution:
Dicrotic notch is caused by closing of aortic valve.

The dicrotic notch, a small oscillation in the falling phase of the pulse wave caused by vibrations set up when the aortic valve shuts.

questions.text: First heart sound and second heart sound are respectively due to ________

choices.text: Opening of semilunar and atrioventricular valves
Closure of semilunar and atrioventricular valves
Closure of atrioventricular and semilunar valves
Opening of atrioventricular  and semilunar valves

questions.solution:
First heart sound and second heart sound are respectively due to closure of atrioventricular (AV) and semilunar valves.

questions.text: The fourth heart sound is caused by:

choices.text: Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Closure of mitral  and tricuspid valves

questions.solution:
The fourth heart sound is caused by ventricular filling.

A fourth sound is heard immediately before the first sound when atrial pressure is high or the ventricle is stiff in conditions such as ventricular hypertrophy. It is due to ventricular filling and is rarely heard in normal adults.

questions.text: “a” wave on JVP is for
questions.solution:
"a" wave in JVP represents atrial contraction.

Waves of JVP :

  • a- atrial systole pushing the blood to the ventricles.
  • c- isovolumetric contraction of ventricles causing the tricuspid valve to bulge.
  • x'- fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to pull of valve leaflets.
  • v- venous filling which creates an increase in atrial pressure.
  • y- passive filling of ventricles by a passive flow of the blood from the right atrium.

questions.text: 'c' wave in JVP is seen in

choices.text: Slow filling at end of diastole

questions.solution: 'c' waves are produced by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during the Iso-volumetric contraction of the right ventricle.

questions.text: The x descent in jugular venous pressure corresponds to _______ phase of the cardiac cycle.
questions.solution:
The x descent in jugular venous pressure corresponds to the ventricular systole of the cardiac cycle.

The jugular venous pulse

  • The waves in JVP reflect the pressure changes in the right atrium.
  • The internal jugular vein is preferred because the external jugular vein is valved and not directly in line with the superior vena cava and right atrium.
  • a wave: Corresponds to right atrial contraction.
  • c wave: Corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • x descent: Corresponds to the atrial relaxation as the ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve during ejection.
  • v wave: Corresponds to the venous filling of the right atrium against a closed tricuspid valve.
  • y descent: Corresponds to fall in right atrial pressure during passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents:

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.solution:
'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

Characteristics of JVP :

  • a wave corresponds to atrial systole which causes regurgitation of some blood into the great veins.
  • c wave occurs due to the increase in atrial pressure caused by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • x descent occurs due to the fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to pulling of valve leaflets.
  • v wave is seen at the end of ventricular contraction and occurs due to the slow venous filling which causes an increase in atrial pressure.
  • y descent occurs due to the passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is:
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge reflex.

Atrial Reflex Control of Heart Rate: The Bainbridge Reflex

  • The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain.
  • Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Bezold-Jarisch Reflex:

  • Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Cushing Reflex:

  • When ICP is increased, the blood supply to RVLM neurons is compromised.
  • The local hypoxia and hypercapnia causes an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia and irregular respiration.
  • The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

questions.text:
Arrange the following events in the sequence in which they occur, after 'p wave' in ECG:
  1. a wave in JVP
  2. First heart sound
  3. Rapid filling of ventricles
  4. T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events that occur after the p-wave is 1-2-4-3, ie:-

a wave in JVP → First heart sound  → T wave in ECG  → Rapid filling of ventricles.

The sequence of the events in this question can be better understood with the following diagram:

  • The p wave in the ECG represents atrial depolarization, which causes contraction of the atria, represented by the 'a' wave in the JVP. Atrial contraction causes final filling of the ventricles (fourth phase of ventricular diastole) 
  • Atrial contraction is followed by the closure of the mitral valve, which causes the first-heart sound.
  • This is followed by the isovolumetric contraction of the ventricle, which causes c wave in JVP, due to bulging of the tricuspid valve. This is followed by the rapid ejection phase of the ventricle.
  • The T wave of ECG occurs during ventricular repolarization, which is followed by the opening of the mitral valve, followed by rapid filling phase of the ventricle (second  phase of ventricular diastole).

Note: Passive rapid filling occurs as the mitral valve opens just before atrial contraction occurs.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: Cardiac output is increased in:
questions.solution:
Cardiac output is increased in pregnancy.

Effect of various conditions on cardiac output:

No change
  • Sleep
  • Moderate changes in environmental temperature
Increase

  • Anxiety and excitement

  •  Eating

  •  Exercise

  • High environmental temperature 
  • Pregnancy 
  • Epinephrine
Decrease
  • Sitting or standing from lying position
  • Rapid arrhythmias 
  • Heart disease
